Consider this review from  a newer generation of gamers, I've grown up with call of duty as my first person shooter, and for a game that come out 22 years ago, it puts the fps' of today to shame. I've played a few of them, and if you're anything like me, you have too, maybe you're even pretty good at it. Great. Now take everything you have learnt from those games, and bin it. This game is nothing like any first person shooter I've ever experienced. Firstly, the AI are MUCH MUCH smarter than you think, it makes you realize how dumbed down current fps' are to appeal to mainstream audience. Then, you come to the actual game play, this is not a game where you can deploy one tactic throughout the entire game, the enemies flush you out, they make you move, and are tactical. You're not some overpowered person destroying everything in your path, you have to be super efficient with the way you use the environment and your arsenal of weapongs.  I played this game on easy difficulty and I found it fairly difficult, so if you're new to this, might want to consider the difficulty. The game had so into it that at times, I suddenly had an urge to pee (just like you do when you used to play hide and seek as a kid). It's all round just incredible, the gameplay has a lot of variety too it, the story has you hooked, and once you get the hang of it, you're going to enjoy it too. But holy **** is it scary at first, maybe its the old graphics, the demonic looking monsters, or the eerie sounds, but I found it scary. Still, all adds to the experience, and if you're looking for a different kind of fps, this is something to give a go. Now I'm off to half life 2.

Experiential storytelling is great, preferable to game-stopping cinematics, and allows for a different experience every playthrough. Visuals are audio are very dated, but this is forgivable due to the game's age and interesting storytelling. The only issues that are rather unforgivable would be the lackluster combat and inconsistent movement mechanics, but these aspects are most definitely improved upon in the later entries to the series.

I thought I would like the game considering its reviews.  I am fully aware this was innovative for its time.  It may be a bit too brutal for some, but I will review it as I would any modern game. Most of the game is ok.  There are 3 major things that ruin it.

1. Old source engine is a buggy mess.  Constantly getting stuck on things forcing you to reload old saves, terrible walking and parkour physics, bleh. Not much to be done about this one.
2. Nothing about the game is straightforward.  Some people like that kind of thing, some people don't.  In general I would say I like games that don't provide you instructions, but somehow I was reaching some later parts of the game without critical components in my toolkit that prevented me from progressing. In addition, some parts of the game have to be performed PERFECTLY in order to not take damage, which is held permanently until healed.  It has to be more straightforward than THAT.
3. Three words.  ON A RAIL.  Seriously, just delete that level.  Never before have I experienced a level that made me want to hate an otherwise ok game. Who created that piece of crap?

Half-Life is an absolute classic game which stands up very well today. It's an FPS that will hand your booty to you if you don't think things through. It was advertised as a smart shooter and it lives up to it. The graphics, in my opinion, are timeless and have a certain charm to them. However, as all games do, this one has some flaws. Many parts can be frustrating for no real reason. It isn't Dark Souls or a platformer where you simply need to 'get gud.' The game is just poorly designed. And in the last fifth of the game I found myself playing it for the sake of completion than fun. I'd still definitely recommend this game to anyone considering it.
